Location of the four major tennis championships</div>

<p>The <b>Grand Slam</b> tournaments, also called <b>majors</b>, are the four most important annual <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a> events. They offer the most ranking points,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> prize money, public and media attention, the greatest strength and size of field, and greater number of "best of" sets for men. The Grand Slam itinerary consists of the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a> in mid January, the <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a> in May and June, <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a> in July, and the <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> in August and September. Each tournament is played over a period of two weeks. The Australian and United States tournaments are played on <a href="/wiki/Hardcourt" title="Hardcourt">hard courts</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hardcourt_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hardcourt-2">[a]</a></sup> the French on <a href="/wiki/Clay_court" title="Clay court">clay</a>, and Wimbledon on <a href="/wiki/Grass_court" title="Grass court">grass</a>. Wimbledon is the oldest, founded in 1877, followed by the US in 1881, the French in 1891, and the Australian in 1905. However, of these four, only Wimbledon was a major before 1924–25, when all four became designated Grand Slam tournaments. Skipping Grand Slam tournaments—especially the Australian Open because of the remoteness, the inconvenient dates (around Christmas and New Year's Day) and the low prize money—was not unusual before 1982, which was the start of the norm of counting Grand Slam titles.</p>
<p>Grand Slam tournaments are not operated by the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals" title="Association of Tennis Professionals">Association of Tennis Professionals</a> (ATP) or the <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Tennis_Association" title="Women's Tennis Association">Women's Tennis Association</a> (WTA), which were formally founded in 1972 and 1973 respectively, though the ATP and WTA do award ranking points based on a player's performance at a major.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[3]</a></sup></p>
<p>The term <i>Grand Slam</i>, without qualification, and also originally, refers to the achievement of winning all four major championships within a single calendar year within one of the five events: men's and women's singles; men's, women's, and mixed doubles. In doubles, one team may accomplish a Grand Slam playing together or one player may achieve it with different partners.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[6]</a></sup></p>
<p>Winning the four majors in consecutive tournaments but not in the same year is known as a Non-Calendar Year Grand Slam, while winning all four majors at any point during the course of a career is known as a Career Grand Slam. Winning the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_medal" title="Olympic medal">gold medal</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the Summer Olympics">Summer Olympic Games</a> in addition to the four majors in one calendar year is known as a "Golden Grand Slam" or more commonly the "Golden Slam". Also, winning the Year-End Championship (known as <a href="/wiki/ATP_Finals" title="ATP Finals">ATP Finals</a> for men's singles and doubles disciplines, and <a href="/wiki/WTA_Finals" title="WTA Finals">WTA Finals</a> for both women's disciplines) in the same period is known as a "Super Slam". Together, all four Majors in all three disciplines (singles, doubles, and mixed doubles) are called a "boxed set" of Grand Slam titles. No male or female player has won all twelve events in one calendar year, although a "career boxed set" has been achieved by three female players.</p>
<p></p>

<h2><span id="Origin_of_the_term_.22Grand_Slam.22"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Origin_of_the_term_"Grand_Slam"">Origin of the term "Grand Slam"</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: Origin of the term "Grand Slam"">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The term <i><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_contract_bridge_terms#S" title="Glossary of contract bridge terms">slam</a></i> for winning all of the tricks in the <a href="/wiki/Category:Whist_family_of_card_games" title="Category:Whist family of card games">whist family card games</a> (see also <a href="/wiki/Whist#Whist_terms" title="Whist">whist terms</a>) is attested from early in the 17th century. <i>Grand slam</i> for all of the tricks, in contrast to <i>small slam</i> or <i>little slam</i> for all but one, dates from early in the 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[7]</a></sup> This use was inherited by <a href="/wiki/Contract_bridge" title="Contract bridge">contract bridge</a>, a modern development of whist defined in 1925 that became very popular in Britain and America by 1930.</p>
<p><i>Grand slam</i> has been <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(golf)" title="Grand Slam (golf)">used in golf</a> since 1930, when <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Jones_(golfer)" title="Bobby Jones (golfer)">Bobby Jones</a> won the four major championships, two British and two American tournaments. Although John F. Kieran of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> is widely credited with first applying the term "grand slam" to tennis to describe the winning of all four major tennis tournaments in a calendar year,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[8]</a></sup> sports columnist Alan Gould had used the term in that connection almost two months before Kieran.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[9]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The possibility of being the reigning champion of all the current four Majors did not exist until 1924–25, when the <a href="/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation" title="International Tennis Federation">International Lawn Tennis Federation</a> designated the Australasian, French (before 1925 only open to members of French tennis clubs), British and American championship tournaments as the four Majors. Before that time only three events: Wimbledon, the <a href="/wiki/World_Hard_Court_Championships" title="World Hard Court Championships">World Hard Court Championships</a> (held in Paris & once in Brussels) and the <a href="/wiki/World_Covered_Court_Championships" title="World Covered Court Championships">World Covered Court Championships</a> (held in various locations) were considered the premier international tennis events by the ILTF.<sup id="cite_ref-wccc_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wccc-11">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-eot_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eot-12">[11]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tony_Wilding" class="mw-redirect" title="Tony Wilding">Tony Wilding</a> of New Zealand won all three of those earlier majors in one year: 1913. It has been possible to complete a Grand Slam in most years and most disciplines since 1925. It was not possible from 1940 to 1945 because of interruptions at Wimbledon, the Australian and French opens due to the Second World War, the years from 1970 to 1985 when there was no Australian tournament in mixed doubles, and 1986 when there was no Australian Open at all.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Phil_Dent" title="Phil Dent">Phil Dent</a> has pointed out that skipping Grand Slam tournaments—especially the Australian Open—was not unusual then, before counting major titles became the norm.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[12]</a></sup> Thus, many players had never played the Austral(as)ian amateur or open championships: the Doherty brothers, <a href="/wiki/William_Larned" title="William Larned">William Larned</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maurice_McLoughlin" title="Maurice McLoughlin">Maurice McLoughlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beals_Wright" title="Beals Wright">Beals Wright</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Johnston_(tennis)" title="Bill Johnston (tennis)">Bill Johnston</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Tilden" title="Bill Tilden">Bill Tilden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Lacoste" title="René Lacoste">René Lacoste</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henri_Cochet" title="Henri Cochet">Henri Cochet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Riggs" title="Bobby Riggs">Bobby Riggs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jack_Kramer" title="Jack Kramer">Jack Kramer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ted_Schroeder" title="Ted Schroeder">Ted Schroeder</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pancho_Gonzales" title="Pancho Gonzales">Pancho Gonzales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Budge_Patty" title="Budge Patty">Budge Patty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Santana" title="Manuel Santana">Manuel Santana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jan_Kode%C5%A1" title="Jan Kodeš">Jan Kodeš</a> and others, while Brookes, <a href="/wiki/Ellsworth_Vines" title="Ellsworth Vines">Ellsworth Vines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaroslav_Drobn%C3%BD" title="Jaroslav Drobný">Jaroslav Drobný</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Orantes" title="Manuel Orantes">Manuel Orantes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilie_N%C4%83stase" title="Ilie Năstase">Ilie Năstase</a> (at 35 years old) and <a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rn_Borg" title="Björn Borg">Björn Borg</a> came just once. Beginning in 1969, when the first Australian Open was held on the <a href="/wiki/Milton_Courts" title="Milton Courts">Milton Courts</a> at Brisbane, the tournament was open to all players, including professionals, who at that point were prohibited from playing the traditional circuit.<sup id="cite_ref-Ausstadiums_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ausstadiums-14">[13]</a></sup> Nevertheless, except for the 1969 and 1971 tournaments, many of the best players missed this championship until 1982, because of the remoteness, the inconvenient dates (around Christmas and New Year's Day) and the low prize money. In 1970, George MacCall's <a href="/wiki/National_Tennis_League" title="National Tennis League">National Tennis League</a>, which employed <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ken_Rosewall" title="Ken Rosewall">Ken Rosewall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Gimeno" title="Andrés Gimeno">Andrés Gimeno</a>, Pancho Gonzales, <a href="/wiki/Roy_Emerson" title="Roy Emerson">Roy Emerson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fred_Stolle" title="Fred Stolle">Fred Stolle</a>, prevented its players from entering the tournament because the guarantees were insufficient. The tournament was won by <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Ashe" title="Arthur Ashe">Arthur Ashe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[14]</a></sup></p>
<p>In terms of the current four majors, the first to win all four in a single year was <a href="/wiki/Don_Budge" title="Don Budge">Don Budge</a>, who completed the feat in 1938. To date, 17 players have completed a Grand Slam, though only six in the most prestigious singles titles. Of these players, three have won multiple Grand Slams: <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a> accomplished the feat twice in men's singles; <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Court" title="Margaret Court">Margaret Court</a> accomplished the feat three times, in two different disciplines – once in women's singles and twice in mixed doubles; and <a href="/wiki/Esther_Vergeer" title="Esther Vergeer">Esther Vergeer</a> completed a grand slam twice in Women's wheelchair doubles.</p>
<p>The four Junior disciplines, boys' and girls' singles and doubles, provide limited opportunities to achieve a Grand Slam. Players are only eligible from age 13 to 18, with 18-year-olds likely to hold a physical advantage. Only <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Edberg" title="Stefan Edberg">Stefan Edberg</a> has completed the Grand Slam in a Junior discipline.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-calendar_year_Grand_Slam">Non-calendar year Grand Slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=9" title="Edit section: Non-calendar year Grand Slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversy_over_terminology">Controversy over terminology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=10" title="Edit section: Controversy over terminology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1982, the <a href="/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation" title="International Tennis Federation">International Tennis Federation</a> (ITF) began offering a $1 million bonus to any singles player to win four consecutive major titles, no matter the time of completion. Although groups variously identified as the <a href="/wiki/Men%27s_International_Professional_Tennis_Council" title="Men's International Professional Tennis Council">Men's International Professional Tennis Council</a>, "abetted primarily by some British tennis writers",<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup> and "European tennis journalists"<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes1982_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes1982-17">[16]</a></sup> had advocated for the ITF to change the definition of "Grand Slam", ITF General Secretary David Gray made it clear that this was not going to happen. In a 1983 letter to tennis journalist Paul Fein, Gray clarified:</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<p>There seems to be some confusion. The ITF's only initiative in this matter has been the organisation of the offer of a bonus of $1m. to any player who holds all four Grand Slam titles simultaneously [...] In spite of all that we have read on this matter, it has never been my Committee of Management's intention to alter the basis of the classic Grand Slam i.e., the capture of all four titles in a year.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>The ITF's plan was to offer the cash bonus for three years, apparently to encourage players to compete in all four major tournaments as much as to reward success at them.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[17]</a></sup></p>
<p>Even before the ITF had announced their bonus, the Grand Slam controversy had taken on a life of its own. Writing in 1982, Neil Amdur claimed, "Now the sport spins nervously under the influence of big dollars and even bigger egos, and tradition has almost gone the way of white balls and long flannels [...] If the four major tournaments want to offer a $1 million incentive for any player in the future who can sweep their titles—and such talks have been rumored—that bonus would be a welcome addition. But changing what the Grand Slam is all about is like a baseball player believing that he 'hit for the cycle' after slugging a single, double and triple in the first game of a doubleheader and a home run in his first time at bat in the second game."<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes1982_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes1982-17">[16]</a></sup> Despite seeming clarity from the ITF, some journalists suggested that the sport's organizing body had turned its back on history and changed the "rules" of tennis by redefining a Grand Slam. Such confusion continued for years. For instance, when <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf" title="Steffi Graf">Steffi Graf</a> completed the Grand Slam in 1988, George Vecsey wrote, "Even the International Tennis Federation, which should have more respect for history, ruled in 1982 that winning any four straight majors constituted a Grand Slam—and offered a $1 million bonus for it [...] But many tennis people, and most writers, and probably most fans, too, did not accept the new rules, and the I.T.F. has dropped the gimmick."<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[18]</a></sup> Vecsey was only half right: the ITF dropped the "gimmick" of the cash bonus, but it had never changed any rules.</p>
<p>However, the ambiguous way the ITF described the Grand Slam in their Constitution led to journalists continuing to make the same assumption as Vecsey over two decades later. For instance, when <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a> was on the verge of completing a non-calendar year Grand Slam at the <a href="/wiki/2011_Australian_Open" title="2011 Australian Open">2011 Australian Open</a>, one writer observed, "Most traditionalists insist that the 'Grand Slam' should refer only to winning all four titles in a calendar year, although the constitution of the International Tennis Federation, the sports governing body, spells out that 'players who hold all four of these titles at the same time achieve the Grand Slam'."<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[19]</a></sup> This was true until later in 2011, when the ITF edited the description to eliminate all confusion. As it now stands, "The Grand Slam titles are the championships of Australia, France, the United States of America and Wimbledon. Players who hold all four of these titles in one calendar year achieve the 'Grand Slam'."<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[20]</a></sup></p>
<p>When <a href="/wiki/Martina_Navratilova" title="Martina Navratilova">Martina Navratilova</a> won the 1984 French Open and became the reigning champion of all four women's singles events, she was the first player to receive the bonus prize in recognition of her achievement. Some media outlets did, indeed, say that she had won a Grand Slam.<sup id="cite_ref-people.com_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-people.com-22">[21]</a></sup> Others simply noted the ongoing controversy: "Whether the Slam was Grand or Bland or a commercial sham tainted with an asterisk the size of a tennis ball, Martina Navratilova finally did it."<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[22]</a></sup> Although the ITF recognizes what is now unofficially known as the "non-calendar year Grand Slam" on its Roll of Honour, no subsequent player to win four or more majors in a row—Steffi Graf, <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>—has received bonus prize money.</p>
<p>Combining <i>the</i> Grand Slam and non-calendar year Grand Slam, the total number of times that players achieved the feat (of being the reigning champion in all four majors) expands to 18.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Achievements_and_near_misses">Achievements and near misses</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=11" title="Edit section: Achievements and near misses">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Three women have won four or more consecutive major titles since 1970, with Navratilova taking six in a row in 1983–1984. On the men's side, Novak Djokovic was the first singles player since Rod Laver to hold all four major titles at once, which he accomplished between Wimbledon 2015 and the 2016 French Open. Prior to the Open Era, Don Budge received the same accolades in winning the French Championships in 1938, but then completed the more prestigious Grand Slam at the 1938 US Championships, giving him six majors in a row, the only male to ever win more than four consecutive major tournaments.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/The_Bryan_brothers" class="mw-redirect" title="The Bryan brothers">The Bryan brothers</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bob_Bryan" title="Bob Bryan">Bob</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mike_Bryan" title="Mike Bryan">Mike</a>) were the last to achieve a non-calendar year Grand Slam in men's doubles. Several players and teams came up one title short. <a href="/wiki/Todd_Woodbridge" title="Todd Woodbridge">Todd Woodbridge</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mark_Woodforde" title="Mark Woodforde">Mark Woodforde</a>, known collectively as <a href="/wiki/The_Woodies" title="The Woodies">The Woodies</a>, reached the final of the 1997 French Open while holding all the other three titles, but lost to <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Kafelnikov" title="Yevgeny Kafelnikov">Yevgeny Kafelnikov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Vacek" title="Daniel Vacek">Daniel Vacek</a>. In singles, <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras" title="Pete Sampras">Pete Sampras</a> lost the 1994 French Open quarterfinal to fellow countryman <a href="/wiki/Jim_Courier" title="Jim Courier">Jim Courier</a>, having won the previous three majors. <a href="/wiki/Roger_Federer" title="Roger Federer">Roger Federer</a> in 2006 and 2007 and Novak Djokovic in 2012 repeated this, both ultimately losing the French Open final to Rafael Nadal. Nadal himself was prevented from achieving this feat by his countryman <a href="/wiki/David_Ferrer" title="David Ferrer">David Ferrer</a>, who defeated him in the quarterfinal of the 2011 Australian Open, which Nadal entered holding the other three major titles. In women's singles, <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a> lost the 1992 Wimbledon final to <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf" title="Steffi Graf">Steffi Graf</a>, having won the previous three majors. <a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a> in the 1998 French Open semifinal, losing to Seles. In women's doubles, <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Ruano_Pascual" title="Virginia Ruano Pascual">Virginia Ruano Pascual</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paola_Su%C3%A1rez" title="Paola Suárez">Paola Suárez</a> had won three Majors from US Open 2003 to the 2004 French Open, lost at the semifinals to <a href="/wiki/Cara_Black" title="Cara Black">Cara Black</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rennae_Stubbs" title="Rennae Stubbs">Rennae Stubbs</a> in the 2004 Wimbledon, and <a href="/wiki/Sania_Mirza" title="Sania Mirza">Sania Mirza</a> in Wimbledon 2015 to the 2016 Australian Open together with Hingis, but lost in the third round of the 2016 French Open to <a href="/wiki/Barbora_Krej%C4%8D%C3%ADkov%C3%A1" title="Barbora Krejčíková">Barbora Krejčíková</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kate%C5%99ina_Siniakov%C3%A1" title="Kateřina Siniaková">Kateřina Siniaková</a>. In 2017, <a href="/wiki/Bethanie_Mattek-Sands" title="Bethanie Mattek-Sands">Bethanie Mattek-Sands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lucie_%C5%A0af%C3%A1%C5%99ov%C3%A1" title="Lucie Šafářová">Lucie Šafářová</a> had the chance to win four consecutive titles at Wimbledon, but withdrew from their scheduled second round match following an acute knee injury suffered by Mattek-Sands in the second round of the <a href="/wiki/2017_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2017 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles">Ladies' Singles</a> competition.</p>
<p>This list is for those players who achieved a non-calendar Grand Slam, but who failed to win the Grand Slam during the same streak.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career_Grand_Slam">Career Grand Slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=12" title="Edit section: Career Grand Slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The career achievement of all four major championships in one format is termed a <i>Career Grand Slam</i> in that format. Dozens of players have accomplished that (column two) and 17 have doubled it: won a second championship in each of the four majors in one format (column three). Two or more career championships in all four majors is sometimes called a "Multiple Slam Set". Three players have Multiple Slam Sets in two formats, one in three formats, so 22 players are counted in the table (column three). Their achievements are tabulated <a href="#Multiple_Career_Grand_Slams">below</a>.</p>

<p>Eight men and ten women have won Career Grand Slams in singles play (rows one and two); among them two men and five women have at least two Career Grand Slams in singles (column three). Since the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Open_Era" class="mw-redirect" title="Open Era">open era</a>, five men (<a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roger_Federer" title="Roger Federer">Roger Federer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>) and six women (<a href="/wiki/Margaret_Court" title="Margaret Court">Margaret Court</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Evert" title="Chris Evert">Chris Evert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martina_Navratilova" title="Martina Navratilova">Martina Navratilova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf" title="Steffi Graf">Steffi Graf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maria_Sharapova" title="Maria Sharapova">Maria Sharapova</a>) have achieved this.</p>
<p>Several singles players have won three major championships without achieving the Career Grand Slam, grouped by the <i>missing</i> Grand Slam tournament:</p>
<ul>
<li>Australian Open: <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Lacoste" title="René Lacoste">René Lacoste</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henri_Cochet" title="Henri Cochet">Henri Cochet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helen_Wills" title="Helen Wills">Helen Wills</a>, <a href="/wiki/Althea_Gibson" title="Althea Gibson">Althea Gibson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tony_Trabert" title="Tony Trabert">Tony Trabert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Osborne_duPont" title="Margaret Osborne duPont">Margaret Osborne duPont</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Santana" title="Manuel Santana">Manuel Santana</a></li>
<li>French Open: <a href="/wiki/Frank_Sedgman" title="Frank Sedgman">Frank Sedgman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ashley_Cooper_(tennis)" title="Ashley Cooper (tennis)">Ashley Cooper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louise_Brough_Clapp" class="mw-redirect" title="Louise Brough Clapp">Louise Brough Clapp</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Wade" title="Virginia Wade">Virginia Wade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Ashe" title="Arthur Ashe">Arthur Ashe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras" title="Pete Sampras">Pete Sampras</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Newcombe" title="John Newcombe">John Newcombe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Connors" title="Jimmy Connors">Jimmy Connors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boris_Becker" title="Boris Becker">Boris Becker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Edberg" title="Stefan Edberg">Stefan Edberg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Davenport" title="Lindsay Davenport">Lindsay Davenport</a></li>
<li>Wimbledon: <a href="/wiki/Ken_Rosewall" title="Ken Rosewall">Ken Rosewall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hana_Mandl%C3%ADkov%C3%A1" title="Hana Mandlíková">Hana Mandlíková</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Lendl" title="Ivan Lendl">Ivan Lendl</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Vilas" title="Guillermo Vilas">Guillermo Vilas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mats_Wilander" title="Mats Wilander">Mats Wilander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Justine_Henin" title="Justine Henin">Justine Henin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka" title="Stan Wawrinka">Stan Wawrinka</a></li>
<li>US Open: <a href="/wiki/Jean_Borotra" title="Jean Borotra">Jean Borotra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jack_Crawford_(tennis)" title="Jack Crawford (tennis)">Jack Crawford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lew_Hoad" title="Lew Hoad">Lew Hoad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angela_Mortimer" title="Angela Mortimer">Angela Mortimer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Evonne_Goolagong_Cawley" title="Evonne Goolagong Cawley">Evonne Goolagong Cawley</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Several doubles players have won three major championships without achieving the Career Grand Slam:</p>
<ul>
<li>Australian Open: <a href="/wiki/John_Van_Ryn" title="John Van Ryn">John Van Ryn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helen_Wills" title="Helen Wills">Helen Wills</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Ryan" title="Elizabeth Ryan">Elizabeth Ryan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Osborne_duPont" title="Margaret Osborne duPont">Margaret Osborne duPont</a>, <a href="/wiki/Darlene_Hard" title="Darlene Hard">Darlene Hard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billie_Jean_King" title="Billie Jean King">Billie Jean King</a>, <a href="/wiki/Betty_St%C3%B6ve" title="Betty Stöve">Betty Stöve</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Seguso" title="Robert Seguso">Robert Seguso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahesh_Bhupathi" title="Mahesh Bhupathi">Mahesh Bhupathi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Davenport" title="Lindsay Davenport">Lindsay Davenport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ekaterina_Makarova" title="Ekaterina Makarova">Ekaterina Makarova</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elena_Vesnina" title="Elena Vesnina">Elena Vesnina</a>.</li>
<li>French Open: <a href="/wiki/John_Bromwich" title="John Bromwich">John Bromwich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Richey" title="Nancy Richey">Nancy Richey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arantxa_S%C3%A1nchez_Vicario" title="Arantxa Sánchez Vicario">Arantxa Sánchez Vicario</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cara_Black" title="Cara Black">Cara Black</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sania_Mirza" title="Sania Mirza">Sania Mirza</a></li>
<li>Wimbledon: <a href="/wiki/Vic_Seixas" title="Vic Seixas">Vic Seixas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ashley_Cooper_(tennis)" title="Ashley Cooper (tennis)">Ashley Cooper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Wade" title="Virginia Wade">Virginia Wade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Ruano_Pascual" title="Virginia Ruano Pascual">Virginia Ruano Pascual</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paola_Su%C3%A1rez" title="Paola Suárez">Paola Suárez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bethanie_Mattek-Sands" title="Bethanie Mattek-Sands">Bethanie Mattek-Sands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lucie_%C5%A0af%C3%A1%C5%99ov%C3%A1" title="Lucie Šafářová">Lucie Šafářová</a></li>
<li>US Open: <a href="/wiki/Jean_Borotra" title="Jean Borotra">Jean Borotra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Brugnon" title="Jacques Brugnon">Jacques Brugnon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jack_Crawford_(tennis)" title="Jack Crawford (tennis)">Jack Crawford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Althea_Gibson" title="Althea Gibson">Althea Gibson</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Only six players have completed a Career Grand Slam in both singles and doubles: one male (<a href="/wiki/Roy_Emerson" title="Roy Emerson">Roy Emerson</a>) and five female (<a href="/wiki/Margaret_Court" title="Margaret Court">Margaret Court</a>, <a href="/wiki/Doris_Hart" title="Doris Hart">Doris Hart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shirley_Fry_Irvin" title="Shirley Fry Irvin">Shirley Fry Irvin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martina_Navratilova" title="Martina Navratilova">Martina Navratilova</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a>). Court, Hart and Navratilova are the only three players to have completed a "Career Boxed Set", winning all four titles in singles, doubles, and mixed doubles; this has never been done by a male player.</p>
<p>The remainder of this section is a complete list, by format, of all players who have won the Career Grand Slam. Players are ordered chronologically by their completion of the Slam.</p>
<h3><span id="Men.27s_singles"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Men's_singles">Men's singles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=13" title="Edit section: Men's singles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Eight men have won all four grand slam tournaments. Two of the eight men achieved a <a href="#Multiple_Career_Grand_Slams">double career Slam</a>. Originally, the grand slams were held on grass (Australian, Wimbledon, and US Open) and clay (French) and the first four players achieved their grand slams on two surfaces. The US Open changed its surface from grass to clay in 1975 and then to hard court in 1978. The Australian Open changed from grass to hard court in 1988. The last four players (Agassi, Federer, Nadal, Djokovic) achieved their grand slam on three different surfaces: hard court, clay, and grass.</p>

<p>At Men's Doubles, 21 players have won the career Slam, including fourteen who achieved the Slam with a unique partner. <h3><span id="Women.27s_doubles"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Women's_doubles">Women's doubles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=16" title="Edit section: Women's doubles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>At Women's Doubles, 21 players have won the career Slam, including ten who achieved the Slam with a unique partner. Nine of the 21 achieved at least a <a href="#Multiple_Career_Grand_Slams">double career Slam</a> at Women's Doubles, led by Martina Navratilova with seven or more titles in each Major.</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mixed_doubles">Mixed doubles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=17" title="Edit section: Mixed doubles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>At Mixed Doubles, a total of 17 players have won the career Slam, including seven who won all four events with the same partner — an odd number because Margaret Court accomplished a career Grand Slam separately with Ken Fletcher and Marty Riessen. The two other teams which won all four events are Doris Hart with Frank Sedgman, and Martina Hingis with Leander Paes. Four of the 17 players have accomplished <a href="#Multiple_Career_Grand_Slams">multiple career Grand Slams</a> in mixed doubles, led by Margaret Court's quadruple Slam.</p>

<ul>
<li>6: <a href="/wiki/Don_Budge" title="Don Budge">Don Budge</a> (from the 1937 <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a> to the 1938 <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">U.S. Championships</a>).</li>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Most_Grand_Slam_singles_titles_without_a_loss">Most Grand Slam singles titles without a loss</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=35" title="Edit section: Most Grand Slam singles titles without a loss">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Helen_Wills_Moody" class="mw-redirect" title="Helen Wills Moody">Helen Wills Moody</a> won all 16 of the Grand Slam singles tournaments she played beginning with the 1924 U.S. Championships and extending to the 1933 Wimbledon Championships (not counting her defaults in the 1926 French and Wimbledon Championships). During this period, she won 6 Wimbledons, 4 French Championships, and 6 U.S. Championships. She also won the <a href="/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics" title="1924 Summer Olympics">1924 Summer Olympics</a> during this period. Moody never entered the Australian Championships.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Most_Grand_Slam_mixed_doubles_titles_without_a_loss">Most Grand Slam mixed doubles titles without a loss</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=36" title="Edit section: Most Grand Slam mixed doubles titles without a loss">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Doris_Hart" title="Doris Hart">Doris Hart</a> won all 13 of the Grand Slam mixed doubles tournaments she played beginning with the 1951 French Championships and extending to the 1955 U.S. Championships. During this period, she won 5 Wimbledons, 3 French Championships, and 5 U.S. Championships.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Golden_Slam">Golden Slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=37" title="Edit section: Golden Slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Tennis was an <a href="/wiki/Olympic_sports" title="Olympic sports">Olympic sport</a> from the inaugural <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1896_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 1896 Summer Olympics">1896 Summer Olympics</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 1924 Summer Olympics">1924 Games</a>, then was dropped for the next 64 years (except as a <a href="/wiki/Demonstration_sport" title="Demonstration sport">demonstration sport</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1968_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 1968 Summer Olympics">1968</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1984_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 1984 Summer Olympics">1984</a>) before returning in <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1988_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 1988 Summer Olympics">1988</a>. As there were only three Major championships designated by the International Lawn Tennis Federation before 1925, none of the tennis players who participated in the Olympics between 1896 and 1924 had a chance to complete a Golden Grand Slam. However, there was a possibility to complete a Career Golden Grand Slam by winning the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1920_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 1920 Summer Olympics">1920 Olympics</a> or <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 1924 Summer Olympics">1924 Olympics</a> plus each of the four grand slams, all of which were present from 1925 onwards. The term <i>Golden Slam</i> (initially "Golden Grand Slam") was coined in 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-tennis.com_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tennis.com-24">[23]</a></sup></p>
<p>Only one player has completed the Golden Slam:<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[25]</a></sup></p>
<dl>
<dd><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany"><img alt="Germany" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf" title="Steffi Graf">Steffi Graf</a> (<a href="/wiki/1988_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1988 Australian Open – Women's Singles">1988 Australian Open</a>, <a href="/wiki/1988_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1988 French Open – Women's Singles">1988 French Open</a>, <a href="/wiki/1988_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1988 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles">1988 Wimbledon Championships</a>, <a href="/wiki/1988_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1988 US Open – Women's Singles">1988 US Open</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1988_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" class="mw-redirect" title="Tennis at the 1988 Summer Olympics – Women's Singles">1988 Olympic gold medal</a>)</dd>
</dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-calendar_year_Golden_Slam">Non-calendar year Golden Slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=38" title="Edit section: Non-calendar year Golden Slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Winning four consecutive Grand Slam tournaments and <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_Olympic_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="Tennis at the Olympic Games">Olympic event</a> in the period of twelve months, although not in the same year, is called a "Non-calendar year Golden Slam".<sup id="cite_ref-golden_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-golden-27">[26]</a></sup> Only <a href="/wiki/The_Bryan_brothers" class="mw-redirect" title="The Bryan brothers">Bob and Mike Bryan</a> have achieved this by winning the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_doubles" title="Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's doubles">2012 Olympics</a>, <a href="/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles" title="2012 US Open – Men's Doubles">2012 US Open</a>, <a href="/wiki/2013_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles" title="2013 Australian Open – Men's Doubles">2013 Australian Open</a>, <a href="/wiki/2013_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles" title="2013 French Open – Men's Doubles">2013 French Open</a> and <a href="/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles" title="2013 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Doubles">2013 Wimbledon Championships</a>. After they won the final at Wimbledon, this was coined the "Golden Bryan Slam".<sup id="cite_ref-bryanslam_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bryanslam-28">[27]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Career_Golden_Slam">Career Golden Slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=39" title="Edit section: Career Golden Slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>A player who wins all four Grand Slam tournaments and the Olympic gold medal during his or her career is said to have achieved a <i>Career Golden Slam</i>.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Super_Slam">Super Slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=40" title="Edit section: Super Slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Soon after the <a href="/wiki/Open_Era" class="mw-redirect" title="Open Era">Open Era</a> began in 1968, the new professional tours each held a year-end championship (YEC), which are elite tournaments involving only the top performers of the given season. The subsequent return of tennis to the Olympics in 1988 gave rise to the notion of a Super Slam as a combination of Golden Slam and YEC title.<sup id="cite_ref-Super_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Super-29">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[30]</a></sup> Eligible YECs are currently called the <a href="/wiki/ATP_Finals" title="ATP Finals">ATP Finals</a> for men, <a href="/wiki/WTA_Finals" title="WTA Finals">WTA Finals</a> for women, and the <a href="/wiki/Wheelchair_Tennis_Masters" title="Wheelchair Tennis Masters">Wheelchair Tennis Masters</a>.</p>
<p>No player has ever completed the Super Slam in a single season.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-calendar_year_Super_Slam">Non-calendar year Super Slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=41" title="Edit section: Non-calendar year Super Slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Only one player has completed the Super Slam in a period of twelve months:</p>
<dl>
<dd><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany"><img alt="Germany" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf" title="Steffi Graf">Steffi Graf</a> (<a href="/wiki/1987_Virginia_Slims_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="1987 Virginia Slims Championships – Singles">1987 Virginia Slims Championships</a>, <a href="/wiki/1988_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1988 Australian Open – Women's Singles">1988 Australian Open</a>, <a href="/wiki/1988_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1988 French Open – Women's Singles">1988 French Open</a>, <a href="/wiki/1988_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1988 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles">1988 Wimbledon Championships</a>, <a href="/wiki/1988_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1988 US Open – Women's Singles">1988 US Open</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_1988_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" class="mw-redirect" title="Tennis at the 1988 Summer Olympics – Women's Singles">1988 Olympic gold medal</a>)</dd>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Three_Major_tournament_titles_in_a_year">Three Major tournament titles in a year</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=43" title="Edit section: Three Major tournament titles in a year">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Players who have won three of the four Grand Slam tournaments in the same year. Jack Crawford, Lew Hoad, Martina Navratilova and Serena Williams won the first three events, but lost the last grand slam tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-1984australianopen_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1984australianopen-32">[b]</a></sup> Crawford, an <a href="/wiki/Asthmatic" class="mw-redirect" title="Asthmatic">asthmatic</a>, won two of the first three sets of the 1933 U.S. Championships final against <a href="/wiki/Fred_Perry" title="Fred Perry">Fred Perry</a>, then tired in the heat and lost the last two sets and the match.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[31]</a></sup></p>
<table border="1px" style="border-collapse:collapse; border-color:#aaa; margin-bottom:0.5em;" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0">
<caption style="text-align:left"><b>Key</b></caption>
<tr>
<td style="background:#00ff00"><b><abbr title="Won tournament">W</abbr></b></td>
<td style="background:#D8BFD8"> <abbr title="Reached final">F</abbr> </td>
<td style="background:yellow"><abbr title="Reached semifinal">SF</abbr></td>
<td style="background:#ffebcd"><abbr title="Reached quarterfinal">QF</abbr></td>
<td style="background:#afeeee"><abbr title="Out in earlier round">#R</abbr></td>
<td style="background:#afeeee"><abbr title="Round-robin">RR</abbr></td>
<td><abbr title="Out in qualification round">Q#</abbr></td>
<td><abbr title="Absent">A</abbr></td>
<td><abbr title="Tournament not held">NH</abbr></td>
</tr>
</table>
<div class="refbegin" style="">(W) Won; (F) finalist; (SF) semifinalist; (QF) quarterfinalist; (#R) rounds 4, 3, 2, 1; (RR) round-robin stage; (Q#) qualification round; (A) absent; (NH) not held.</div>
<div class="refbegin" style="">To avoid confusion and double counting, these charts are updated at the conclusion of a tournament or when the player's participation has ended.</div>

</dl>

<p><small><b>Note:</b> From 1977 to 1985, the Australian Open was held in December as the last Major of the calendar year.</small></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Four_Major_tournament_finals_in_a_year">Four Major tournament finals in a year</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=44" title="Edit section: Four Major tournament finals in a year">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Players who have played all the four Grand Slam tournaments in the same year.</p>
<table border="1px" style="border-collapse:collapse; border-color:#aaa; margin-bottom:0.5em;" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0">
<caption style="text-align:left"><b>Key</b></caption>
<tr>
<td style="background:#00ff00"><b><abbr title="Won tournament">W</abbr></b></td>
<td style="background:#D8BFD8"> <abbr title="Reached final">F</abbr> </td>
<td style="background:yellow"><abbr title="Reached semifinal">SF</abbr></td>
<td style="background:#ffebcd"><abbr title="Reached quarterfinal">QF</abbr></td>
<td style="background:#afeeee"><abbr title="Out in earlier round">#R</abbr></td>
<td style="background:#afeeee"><abbr title="Round-robin">RR</abbr></td>
<td><abbr title="Out in qualification round">Q#</abbr></td>
<td><abbr title="Absent">A</abbr></td>
<td><abbr title="Tournament not held">NH</abbr></td>
</tr>
</table>
<div class="refbegin" style="">(W) Won; (F) finalist; (SF) semifinalist; (QF) quarterfinalist; (#R) rounds 4, 3, 2, 1; (RR) round-robin stage; (Q#) qualification round; (A) absent; (NH) not held.</div>
<div class="refbegin" style="">To avoid confusion and double counting, these charts are updated at the conclusion of a tournament or when the player's participation has ended.</div>

<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Triple_Crown">Triple Crown</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=45" title="Edit section: Triple Crown">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Winning singles, doubles and mixed doubles titles at one Grand Slam event is called a Triple Crown.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[36]</a></sup> It has become a rare accomplishment in tennis. This is partly because the final match in all three disciplines often takes place concurrently in the same day if not in consecutive days. Doris Hart for example attained her first Triple Crown after playing three Wimbledon final matches held in one single day.</p>
<p>Notes:</p>
<ul>
<li>This list excludes the 1909 triple crown of <a href="/wiki/Jeanne_Matthey" title="Jeanne Matthey">Jeanne Matthey</a> and the 1920, 1921, 1922 and 1923 triple crown wins of <a href="/wiki/Suzanne_Lenglen" title="Suzanne Lenglen">Suzanne Lenglen</a>. The French Championship tennis tournament at the time was a domestic competition not recognized as an international major. At the time the major clay court event (actual precursor of the French Open in its current international format) was the <a href="/wiki/World_Hard_Court_Championships" title="World Hard Court Championships">World Hard Court Championships</a>, where Suzanne Lenglen also attained triple championship in 1921 and 1922).</li>
<li>Also the 1941 triple championship of <a href="/wiki/Alice_Weiwers" title="Alice Weiwers">Alice Weiwers</a> is not listed due to its disputed official status: French championships held in <a href="/wiki/Vichy_France" title="Vichy France">Vichy France</a> from 1941 to 1945 are currently not recognized by <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Fran%C3%A7aise_de_Tennis" title="Fédération Française de Tennis">Fédération Française de Tennis</a>.</li>
</ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Boxed_Set">Boxed Set</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=46" title="Edit section: Boxed Set">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Another Grand Slam-related accomplishment is winning a "boxed set" of Grand Slam titles – which is at least one of every possible type of Major championship available to a player: the singles, doubles, and mixed doubles at all four Grand Slam events of the year. This has never been accomplished within a year or consecutively across two calendar years.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Career_Boxed_Set">Career Boxed Set</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=47" title="Edit section: Career Boxed Set">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The Career Boxed Set refers to winning one of every possible grand slam title (singles, doubles, mixed) over the course of an entire career. No male player has completed this, although Frank Sedgman only missed out on the French Open singles title. Men who participate in top/elite level singles have played comparatively few doubles, and very few mixed doubles. So far, only three women have completed the boxed set during their careers:</p>

<p>Court is not only unique in having two boxed sets, but is also unique in the timing of her accomplishments. Her first boxed set was completed before the start of the open era, and she has a boxed set achieved solely within the open era.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a> was the most recent player to be one title away from joining this elite group. She only needed the French Open singles, having reached the final in 1997 and 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[37]</a></sup> Prior to Hingis, it was <a href="/wiki/Billie_Jean_King" title="Billie Jean King">Billie Jean King</a> who came close at completing a career boxed set. She only needed the Australian Open women's doubles title, having reached the final in 1965 and 1969.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Multiple_Career_Grand_Slams">Multiple Career Grand Slams</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=48" title="Edit section: Multiple Career Grand Slams">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Of the many players who have managed to win a full set of four majors, there is a small number who have gone on to win all four majors a second or more times. The completion of "Multiple Career Grand Slams" or sometimes called "multiple slam sets" (MSS) has been achieved by only 22 unique players up to the end of the 2015 Wimbledon. MSS players can be found in each of the five tennis disciplines: men's or women's singles, men's or women's doubles, mixed doubles. It can also be found in women's wheelchair doubles. Of these, five players have completed MSS in more than one discipline: <a href="/wiki/Roy_Emerson" title="Roy Emerson">Roy Emerson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martina_Navratilova" title="Martina Navratilova">Martina Navratilova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frank_Sedgman" title="Frank Sedgman">Frank Sedgman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams" title="Serena Williams">Serena Williams</a> have MSS in two disciplines, <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Court" title="Margaret Court">Margaret Court</a> has MSS in three disciplines.</p>
<p>This table shows each multiple occurrence of a complete MSS for each of the players who have accomplished multiple slams in a particular tennis discipline. The year shown for each of the four majors is the year that particular major win was repeated as part of that player's achievement of their second (all 22 players) and third (8 players) and fourth (4 players) and fifth through seventh (Martina Navratilova, in women's doubles) complete slam set of Major wins.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (May 2012)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>For example, the fourth row shows that Margaret Court completed her third career slam set in Women's Singles—winning each of the four majors three times—during the 1970 Wimbledon Championships (bold). More specific, she won: Australian open 11 times, the third in 1962; French Open five times, the third in 1969; Wimbledon three times (determines the maximum of sets), the third in 1970 and finally US Open five times, the third in 1969. Grey background shades lesser achievements by the same player in the same discipline (e.g., Court in the eighth row); yellow highlights the greatest achievement in the discipline (e.g., Graf in the third row).</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Pro_Slam">Pro Slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Slam_(tennis)&action=edit&section=49" title="Edit section: Pro Slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Before the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_open_era" class="mw-redirect" title="Tennis open era">Open Era</a> began in 1968, only amateur players were allowed to compete in the four majors. Many male top players "went pro" in order to win prize money legally, competing on a professional world tour comprising completely different events.<sup id="cite_ref-eot1974_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eot1974-42">[38]</a></sup> From 1927 through 1967, the three oldest pro events were considered "majors" of the pro tour: the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Pro_Tennis_Championships" title="U.S. Pro Tennis Championships">U.S. Pro Tennis Championships</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_Pro_Championship" title="French Pro Championship">French Pro Championship</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Championships" title="Wembley Championships">Wembley Championships</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RGeist_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RGeist-43">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RLee_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RLee-44">[40]</a></sup> A player who won all three in a calendar year was considered to achieve a "Professional Grand Slam", or "Pro Slam".<sup id="cite_ref-RGeist_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RGeist-43">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RLee_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RLee-44">[40]</a></sup> The feat was accomplished twice:</p>
<dl>
<dd><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia"><img alt="Australia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="640" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Ken_Rosewall" title="Ken Rosewall">Ken Rosewall</a> in 1963;<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[41]</a></sup></dd>
<dd><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia"><img alt="Australia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="640" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a> in 1967.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[42]</a></sup></dd>
</dl>
<p>Three other players won those three major trophies during their pro careers: <a href="/wiki/Ellsworth_Vines" title="Ellsworth Vines">Ellsworth Vines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hans_N%C3%BCsslein" title="Hans Nüsslein">Hans Nüsslein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Don_Budge" title="Don Budge">Don Budge</a>. The pro slams did not have a women's draw.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title=" (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>

Location of the four major tennis championships

The Grand Slam tournaments, also called majors, are the four most important annual tennis events. They offer the most ranking points,[1] prize money, public and media attention, the greatest strength and size of field, and greater number of "best of" sets for men. The Grand Slam itinerary consists of the Australian Open in mid January, the French Open in May and June, Wimbledon in July, and the US Open in August and September. Each tournament is played over a period of two weeks. The Australian and United States tournaments are played on hard courts,[a] the French on clay, and Wimbledon on grass. Wimbledon is the oldest, founded in 1877, followed by the US in 1881, the French in 1891, and the Australian in 1905. However, of these four, only Wimbledon was a major before 1924–25, when all four became designated Grand Slam tournaments. Skipping Grand Slam tournaments—especially the Australian Open because of the remoteness, the inconvenient dates (around Christmas and New Year's Day) and the low prize money—was not unusual before 1982, which was the start of the norm of counting Grand Slam titles.

Grand Slam tournaments are not operated by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) or the Women's Tennis Association (WTA), which were formally founded in 1972 and 1973 respectively, though the ATP and WTA do award ranking points based on a player's performance at a major.[2][3]

The term Grand Slam, without qualification, and also originally, refers to the achievement of winning all four major championships within a single calendar year within one of the five events: men's and women's singles; men's, women's, and mixed doubles. In doubles, one team may accomplish a Grand Slam playing together or one player may achieve it with different partners.[4][5][6]

Winning the four majors in consecutive tournaments but not in the same year is known as a Non-Calendar Year Grand Slam, while winning all four majors at any point during the course of a career is known as a Career Grand Slam. Winning the gold medal at the Summer Olympic Games in addition to the four majors in one calendar year is known as a "Golden Grand Slam" or more commonly the "Golden Slam". Also, winning the Year-End Championship (known as ATP Finals for men's singles and doubles disciplines, and WTA Finals for both women's disciplines) in the same period is known as a "Super Slam". Together, all four Majors in all three disciplines (singles, doubles, and mixed doubles) are called a "boxed set" of Grand Slam titles. No male or female player has won all twelve events in one calendar year, although a "career boxed set" has been achieved by three female players.

Origin of the term "Grand Slam"[edit]

The term slam for winning all of the tricks in the whist family card games (see also whist terms) is attested from early in the 17th century. Grand slam for all of the tricks, in contrast to small slam or little slam for all but one, dates from early in the 19th century.[7] This use was inherited by contract bridge, a modern development of whist defined in 1925 that became very popular in Britain and America by 1930.

Grand slam has been used in golf since 1930, when Bobby Jones won the four major championships, two British and two American tournaments. Although John F. Kieran of The New York Times is widely credited with first applying the term "grand slam" to tennis to describe the winning of all four major tennis tournaments in a calendar year,[8] sports columnist Alan Gould had used the term in that connection almost two months before Kieran.[9]

History[edit]

The possibility of being the reigning champion of all the current four Majors did not exist until 1924–25, when the International Lawn Tennis Federation designated the Australasian, French (before 1925 only open to members of French tennis clubs), British and American championship tournaments as the four Majors. Before that time only three events: Wimbledon, the World Hard Court Championships (held in Paris & once in Brussels) and the World Covered Court Championships (held in various locations) were considered the premier international tennis events by the ILTF.[10][11] Tony Wilding of New Zealand won all three of those earlier majors in one year: 1913. It has been possible to complete a Grand Slam in most years and most disciplines since 1925. It was not possible from 1940 to 1945 because of interruptions at Wimbledon, the Australian and French opens due to the Second World War, the years from 1970 to 1985 when there was no Australian tournament in mixed doubles, and 1986 when there was no Australian Open at all.

Phil Dent has pointed out that skipping Grand Slam tournaments—especially the Australian Open—was not unusual then, before counting major titles became the norm.[12] Thus, many players had never played the Austral(as)ian amateur or open championships: the Doherty brothers, William Larned, Maurice McLoughlin, Beals Wright, Bill Johnston, Bill Tilden, René Lacoste, Henri Cochet, Bobby Riggs, Jack Kramer, Ted Schroeder, Pancho Gonzales, Budge Patty, Manuel Santana, Jan Kodeš and others, while Brookes, Ellsworth Vines, Jaroslav Drobný, Manuel Orantes, Ilie Năstase (at 35 years old) and Björn Borg came just once. Beginning in 1969, when the first Australian Open was held on the Milton Courts at Brisbane, the tournament was open to all players, including professionals, who at that point were prohibited from playing the traditional circuit.[13] Nevertheless, except for the 1969 and 1971 tournaments, many of the best players missed this championship until 1982, because of the remoteness, the inconvenient dates (around Christmas and New Year's Day) and the low prize money. In 1970, George MacCall's National Tennis League, which employed Rod Laver, Ken Rosewall, Andrés Gimeno, Pancho Gonzales, Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle, prevented its players from entering the tournament because the guarantees were insufficient. The tournament was won by Arthur Ashe.[14]

In terms of the current four majors, the first to win all four in a single year was Don Budge, who completed the feat in 1938. To date, 17 players have completed a Grand Slam, though only six in the most prestigious singles titles. Of these players, three have won multiple Grand Slams: Rod Laver accomplished the feat twice in men's singles; Margaret Court accomplished the feat three times, in two different disciplines – once in women's singles and twice in mixed doubles; and Esther Vergeer completed a grand slam twice in Women's wheelchair doubles.

The four Junior disciplines, boys' and girls' singles and doubles, provide limited opportunities to achieve a Grand Slam. Players are only eligible from age 13 to 18, with 18-year-olds likely to hold a physical advantage. Only Stefan Edberg has completed the Grand Slam in a Junior discipline.

Non-calendar year Grand Slam[edit]

Controversy over terminology[edit]

In 1982, the International Tennis Federation (ITF) began offering a $1 million bonus to any singles player to win four consecutive major titles, no matter the time of completion. Although groups variously identified as the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, "abetted primarily by some British tennis writers",[15] and "European tennis journalists"[16] had advocated for the ITF to change the definition of "Grand Slam", ITF General Secretary David Gray made it clear that this was not going to happen. In a 1983 letter to tennis journalist Paul Fein, Gray clarified:

There seems to be some confusion. The ITF's only initiative in this matter has been the organisation of the offer of a bonus of $1m. to any player who holds all four Grand Slam titles simultaneously [...] In spite of all that we have read on this matter, it has never been my Committee of Management's intention to alter the basis of the classic Grand Slam i.e., the capture of all four titles in a year.

The ITF's plan was to offer the cash bonus for three years, apparently to encourage players to compete in all four major tournaments as much as to reward success at them.[17]

Even before the ITF had announced their bonus, the Grand Slam controversy had taken on a life of its own. Writing in 1982, Neil Amdur claimed, "Now the sport spins nervously under the influence of big dollars and even bigger egos, and tradition has almost gone the way of white balls and long flannels [...] If the four major tournaments want to offer a $1 million incentive for any player in the future who can sweep their titles—and such talks have been rumored—that bonus would be a welcome addition. But changing what the Grand Slam is all about is like a baseball player believing that he 'hit for the cycle' after slugging a single, double and triple in the first game of a doubleheader and a home run in his first time at bat in the second game."[16] Despite seeming clarity from the ITF, some journalists suggested that the sport's organizing body had turned its back on history and changed the "rules" of tennis by redefining a Grand Slam. Such confusion continued for years. For instance, when Steffi Graf completed the Grand Slam in 1988, George Vecsey wrote, "Even the International Tennis Federation, which should have more respect for history, ruled in 1982 that winning any four straight majors constituted a Grand Slam—and offered a $1 million bonus for it [...] But many tennis people, and most writers, and probably most fans, too, did not accept the new rules, and the I.T.F. has dropped the gimmick."[18] Vecsey was only half right: the ITF dropped the "gimmick" of the cash bonus, but it had never changed any rules.

However, the ambiguous way the ITF described the Grand Slam in their Constitution led to journalists continuing to make the same assumption as Vecsey over two decades later. For instance, when Rafael Nadal was on the verge of completing a non-calendar year Grand Slam at the 2011 Australian Open, one writer observed, "Most traditionalists insist that the 'Grand Slam' should refer only to winning all four titles in a calendar year, although the constitution of the International Tennis Federation, the sports governing body, spells out that 'players who hold all four of these titles at the same time achieve the Grand Slam'."[19] This was true until later in 2011, when the ITF edited the description to eliminate all confusion. As it now stands, "The Grand Slam titles are the championships of Australia, France, the United States of America and Wimbledon. Players who hold all four of these titles in one calendar year achieve the 'Grand Slam'."[20]

When Martina Navratilova won the 1984 French Open and became the reigning champion of all four women's singles events, she was the first player to receive the bonus prize in recognition of her achievement. Some media outlets did, indeed, say that she had won a Grand Slam.[21] Others simply noted the ongoing controversy: "Whether the Slam was Grand or Bland or a commercial sham tainted with an asterisk the size of a tennis ball, Martina Navratilova finally did it."[22] Although the ITF recognizes what is now unofficially known as the "non-calendar year Grand Slam" on its Roll of Honour, no subsequent player to win four or more majors in a row—Steffi Graf, Serena Williams, or Novak Djokovic—has received bonus prize money.

Combining the Grand Slam and non-calendar year Grand Slam, the total number of times that players achieved the feat (of being the reigning champion in all four majors) expands to 18.

Achievements and near misses[edit]

Three women have won four or more consecutive major titles since 1970, with Navratilova taking six in a row in 1983–1984. On the men's side, Novak Djokovic was the first singles player since Rod Laver to hold all four major titles at once, which he accomplished between Wimbledon 2015 and the 2016 French Open. Prior to the Open Era, Don Budge received the same accolades in winning the French Championships in 1938, but then completed the more prestigious Grand Slam at the 1938 US Championships, giving him six majors in a row, the only male to ever win more than four consecutive major tournaments.

The Bryan brothers (Bob and Mike) were the last to achieve a non-calendar year Grand Slam in men's doubles. Several players and teams came up one title short. Todd Woodbridge and Mark Woodforde, known collectively as The Woodies, reached the final of the 1997 French Open while holding all the other three titles, but lost to Yevgeny Kafelnikov and Daniel Vacek. In singles, Pete Sampras lost the 1994 French Open quarterfinal to fellow countryman Jim Courier, having won the previous three majors. Roger Federer in 2006 and 2007 and Novak Djokovic in 2012 repeated this, both ultimately losing the French Open final to Rafael Nadal. Nadal himself was prevented from achieving this feat by his countryman David Ferrer, who defeated him in the quarterfinal of the 2011 Australian Open, which Nadal entered holding the other three major titles. In women's singles, Monica Seles lost the 1992 Wimbledon final to Steffi Graf, having won the previous three majors. Martina Hingis in the 1998 French Open semifinal, losing to Seles. In women's doubles, Virginia Ruano Pascual and Paola Suárez had won three Majors from US Open 2003 to the 2004 French Open, lost at the semifinals to Cara Black and Rennae Stubbs in the 2004 Wimbledon, and Sania Mirza in Wimbledon 2015 to the 2016 Australian Open together with Hingis, but lost in the third round of the 2016 French Open to Barbora Krejčíková and Kateřina Siniaková. In 2017, Bethanie Mattek-Sands and Lucie Šafářová had the chance to win four consecutive titles at Wimbledon, but withdrew from their scheduled second round match following an acute knee injury suffered by Mattek-Sands in the second round of the Ladies' Singles competition.

This list is for those players who achieved a non-calendar Grand Slam, but who failed to win the Grand Slam during the same streak.

Career Grand Slam[edit]

The career achievement of all four major championships in one format is termed a Career Grand Slam in that format. Dozens of players have accomplished that (column two) and 17 have doubled it: won a second championship in each of the four majors in one format (column three). Two or more career championships in all four majors is sometimes called a "Multiple Slam Set". Three players have Multiple Slam Sets in two formats, one in three formats, so 22 players are counted in the table (column three). Their achievements are tabulated below.

Career Grand Slams by format
Format Numbers of players
Completed the Career GS Completed at least 2
Men's singles 8 players (2 Golden, 1 Super) 2 players
Women's singles 10 players (2 Golden, 2 Super) 5 players
Men's doubles 21 players (14 as teams) 5 players (2 as a team)
Women's doubles 21 players (10 as teams) 8 players (6 as teams)
Mixed doubles 17 players (7 as teams) 4 players (2 as teams)

Eight men and ten women have won Career Grand Slams in singles play (rows one and two); among them two men and five women have at least two Career Grand Slams in singles (column three). Since the beginning of the open era, five men (Rod Laver, Andre Agassi, Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic) and six women (Margaret Court, Chris Evert, Martina Navratilova, Steffi Graf, Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova) have achieved this.

Several singles players have won three major championships without achieving the Career Grand Slam, grouped by the missing Grand Slam tournament:

  • Australian Open: René Lacoste, Henri Cochet, Helen Wills, Althea Gibson, Tony Trabert, Margaret Osborne duPont, and Manuel Santana
  • French Open: Frank Sedgman, Ashley Cooper, Louise Brough Clapp, Virginia Wade, Arthur Ashe, Pete Sampras, John Newcombe, Jimmy Connors, Boris Becker, Stefan Edberg, Martina Hingis, and Lindsay Davenport
  • Wimbledon: Ken Rosewall, Hana Mandlíková, Ivan Lendl, Monica Seles, Guillermo Vilas, Mats Wilander, Justine Henin, and Stan Wawrinka
  • US Open: Jean Borotra, Jack Crawford, Lew Hoad, Angela Mortimer, and Evonne Goolagong Cawley

Several doubles players have won three major championships without achieving the Career Grand Slam:

  • Australian Open: John Van Ryn, Helen Wills, Elizabeth Ryan, Margaret Osborne duPont, Darlene Hard, Billie Jean King, Betty Stöve, Robert Seguso, Mahesh Bhupathi, Lindsay Davenport, Ekaterina Makarova and Elena Vesnina.
  • French Open: John Bromwich, Nancy Richey, Arantxa Sánchez Vicario, Cara Black, and Sania Mirza
  • Wimbledon: Vic Seixas, Ashley Cooper, Virginia Wade, Virginia Ruano Pascual, Paola Suárez, Bethanie Mattek-Sands, and Lucie Šafářová
  • US Open: Jean Borotra, Jacques Brugnon, Jack Crawford, Althea Gibson, and Rod Laver

Only six players have completed a Career Grand Slam in both singles and doubles: one male (Roy Emerson) and five female (Margaret Court, Doris Hart, Shirley Fry Irvin, Martina Navratilova, and Serena Williams). Court, Hart and Navratilova are the only three players to have completed a "Career Boxed Set", winning all four titles in singles, doubles, and mixed doubles; this has never been done by a male player.

The remainder of this section is a complete list, by format, of all players who have won the Career Grand Slam. Players are ordered chronologically by their completion of the Slam.

Men's singles[edit]

Eight men have won all four grand slam tournaments. Two of the eight men achieved a double career Slam. Originally, the grand slams were held on grass (Australian, Wimbledon, and US Open) and clay (French) and the first four players achieved their grand slams on two surfaces. The US Open changed its surface from grass to clay in 1975 and then to hard court in 1978. The Australian Open changed from grass to hard court in 1988. The last four players (Agassi, Federer, Nadal, Djokovic) achieved their grand slam on three different surfaces: hard court, clay, and grass.

Mixed doubles[edit]

Four of the 17 players have accomplished multiple career Grand Slams in mixed doubles, led by Margaret Court's quadruple Slam.
